2.7.1 Airplanes
In accordance with NCO.OP.125, the PIC shall only commence a flight if the airplane carries sufficient fuel and oil for the following:

VFR Flights (NCO.OP.125 (a)(1))

By day, taking-off and landing at the same aerodrome/landing site and always remaining in sight of that aerodrome/landing site:
to fly the intended route and thereafter for at least 10 minutes at normal cruising altitude;

By day:
to fly to the aerodrome of intended landing and thereafter to fly for at least 30 minutes at normal cruising altitude; or

By night:
to fly to the aerodrome of intended landing and thereafter to fly for at least 45 minutes at normal cruising altitude;

Note: It is EuroPilot Center’s Policy for all VFR flights to have at least 45 minutes final reserve on board.



IFR Flights (NCO.OP.125 (a)(2))

When no destination alternate is required:
to fly to the aerodrome of intended landing and thereafter to fly for at least 45 minutes at normal cruising altitude; or

When a destination alternate is required:
to fly to the aerodrome of intended landing, to an alternate aerodrome and thereafter to fly for at least 45 minutes at normal cruising altitude.

5. MINIMUM EQUIPMENT LIST (MEL)

EuroPilot Center does not apply operational procedures in accordance with NCO.IDE.A.105 to dispatch an aircraft with inoperative equipment through a Minimum Equipment List (MEL).

Alternatively, in accordance with Commission Regulation (EC) No. 2042/2003, M.A.403, any defect that hazards seriously the flight safety shall be rectified before further flight.

Only authorized certifying staff (maintenance engineers) may decide whether an aircraft defect hazards seriously the flight safety and therefore decide when and which rectification action shall be taken before further flight and which defect rectification can be deferred.

Any aircraft defect that would not hazard seriously the flight safety shall be rectified as soon as practicable after the date the defect was first identified and within any limits specified in the maintenance data.

Any defect not rectified before flight shall be recorded in the aircraft maintenance record system and all deferred defects shall be made known to the pilot / flight crew via the paper and electronic Trouble Report.

Deferred defects shall be transferred by maintenance onto worksheets at the next appropriate maintenance check.

Any deferred defect which is not rectified during the maintenance check shall be re-entered onto a new deferred defect record sheet.

The original date of the defect shall be retained.

The necessary components or parts needed for rectification shall be made available or ordered on a priority basis and fitted at the earliest opportunity.

Note:
As EuroPilot Center has no MEL procedure in place, the decision to defer an aircraft defect cannot be taken by the Pilot-in-Command but must be taken by an authorized maintenance engineer.
The decision to dispatch the aircraft after an item has been deferred lies with the Pilot-in-Command.

4.2.1 Monthly Flight Training Schedule
The flight training schedule covers the planning of the students, instructors and the training fleet.

The flight training schedule is established on a monthly basis, offering both students and instructors more security and a better way to combine flying activities with a private and professional life.

The following scheduling procedure is applied:

Step 1: before the 20th of each month, all instructional staff provides their availabilities for the coming month through the online planning system.
Step 2: around the 20th of each month, an e-mail is sent out by the Chief Operations Officer to all students with the available dates for training for the upcoming month.
Step 3: each individual student feedback is processed, and temporary training slots are allocated in the online planning system. A draft schedule is produced, and completed or modified depending on the feedback from all students.
Step 4: on the 23rd a reminder is sent out to the students who haven’t replied yet.
Step 5: when the schedule is almost complete (usually around the 24th), an e-mail is sent out to each student individually, including a personal training schedule.
Step 6: upon receipt of final confirmation by the student, the training slots are saved into the online planning system. An aircraft, training device and instructor are allocated to the training slot.
Step 7: for each flight training session, a training device (FSTD) is allocated as far as practicable (color green), offering a backup in case of adverse weather conditions.

Changes to the schedule throughout the month can only be performed by the Chief Operations Officer or Operations Officer.

Note 1: In no event should any Flight or Theoretical Knowledge Instructor alter the monthly schedule as this will lead to loss of overview and efficiency.

Note 2: Students are never allowed to reserve training slots with instructor directly via the online planning system, with the exception of self-practice FSTD sessions, which the student may reserve directly (color code blue) via the online planning system. A restriction of maximum 2 hours per student is applicable in order to guarantee every student sufficient self-practice time on the FSTD’s.

Note 3: Flight training sessions on the FSTD (with instructors) always have priority over self-practice FSTD sessions.

2.1 General

In accordance with NCO.OP.135 (a), before commencing a flight, the PIC shall ascertain by every reasonable means available that the space-based facilities (GNSS), ground and/or water facilities, including communication facilities and navigation aids available and directly required on such flight, for the safe operation of the aircraft, are adequate for the type of operation under which the flight is to be conducted.

In accordance with NCO.OP.135 (b), before commencing a flight, the PIC shall be familiar with all available meteorological information appropriate to the intended flight.

Preparation for a flight away from the vicinity of the place of departure, and for every flight under IFR, shall include at least:
• A study of available current weather reports and forecasts; and
• The planning of an alternative course of action to provide for the eventuality that the flight cannot be completed as planned, because of weather conditions.

Further, in accordance with NCO.OP.175, before commencing take-off, the PIC shall be satisfied that:
• According to the information available, the weather at the aerodrome or operating site and the condition of the runway or final approach and take-off areas (FATO’s) intended to be used would not prevent a safe take-off and departure; and
• Applicable aerodrome operating minima will be complied with.

In accordance with NCO.OP.205, before commencing an approach to land, the pilot-in-command shall be satisfied that:
• According to the information available, the weather at the aerodrome or the operating site and the condition of the runway or final approach and take-off areas (FATO’s) intended to be used would not prevent a safe approach, landing or missed approach.

Students are required to be at the airport at least 30 minutes before the scheduled Off Block Time to prepare the flight. 5.3 Pilot Logbook

In accordance with FCL.050, holders of a pilot license shall record details of all flights flown, in a format acceptable to the BCAA responsible for license or rating issue.

This logbook enables pilot license holders to record flying experience in a manner which will facilitate this process while providing a permanent record of the license holders flying.

Pilots who fly regularly airplanes and helicopters, or different aircraft types are recommended to hold separate logbooks for each type of flying.

The logbook entries should be made as soon as practicable after any flight undertaken. All entries in the logbook shall be made in ink or indelible pencil.

The specifics of every flight in the course of which the holder of a pilot license acts as a (student) pilot of an aircraft are to be recorded in the appropriate columns using one line for each flight, provided that if an aircraft carries out a number of flights upon the same day returning on each occasion to the same place of departure and the interval between successive flights does not exceed thirty minutes, such series of flights may be recorded as a single entry.

Flight time for airplanes, touring motor gliders and powered-lift means the total time from the moment an aircraft first moves for the purpose of taking off until the moment it finally comes to rest at the end of the flight; for helicopters, it means the total time from the moment a helicopter’s rotor blades start turning until the moment the helicopter finally comes to rest at the end of the flight, and the rotor blades are stopped.

All flying carried out as Pilot-in-Command shall be entered in the logbook as Pilot-in-Command.

7.1 General

A Duty is any task that a student or instructor is required to carry out associated with the business of an AOC holder or an ATO.

A Duty Period is a period which starts when a student or instructor is required by an operator or an ATO to commence a duty and ends when they are free from all duties.

A Flight Duty Period is any time during which a student or instructor operates in an aircraft as a member of its crew.

The Flight Duty Period starts when the student or instructor is required by an Operator or an ATO to report for a flight or a series of flights; it finishes at the end of the last flight on which he or she is an operating crew member.

A Rest Period is an uninterrupted and defined period of time during which a student or instructor is free from all duties.

The Home Base is the location nominated by EuroPilot Center to the student or instructor from where they normally start and end a Flight Duty Period and where EuroPilot Center is not responsible for their accommodation.

Antwerp Airport (EBAW) is considered as the Home Base for EuroPilot Center.

Instructors or students performing Flight Duties for other Operators or ATO’s are at all times responsible to inform EuroPilot Center about these Flight Duties.

They must ensure that they do not operate an EuroPilot Center aircraft if they know that they have not had sufficient rest or they are suffering from or are likely to suffer from fatigue or feel unfit, to the extent that the flight may be endangered.

EuroPilot Center will keep track of the Flight Duty Periods performed within EuroPilot Center for students and instructors by means of the Blue Cat system.

8.5 Operational Flight Plan (OFP)

The pilot-in-command must ensure that an Operational Flight Plan is produced for each VFR or IFR cross-country training flight.

A cross-country flight is defined as a flight between a point of departure and a point of arrival following a pre-planned route, using standard navigation procedures (dead-reckoning, pilotage and/or radio navigation).

Note:
An Operational Flight Plan is not required for VFR or IFR training flights taking off and landing at the same aerodrome or operating site.

The Operational Flight Plan contains at least the following:

Aircraft registration
Type and variant
Date of flight
Flight identification (Mission code assignment, e.g. 1-1-1)
Names and duty assignments of students and/or instructor
Place of departure
Time of departure (actual off-block time, take-off time)
Place of arrival (planned and actual)
Time of arrival (actual landing and on-block time)
Type of operation (e.g. training flight)
Route and route segment with check-points/waypoints, distances, time and tracks
Planned cruising speed and flying times between check-points/waypoints, estimated and actual times overhead
Safe altitudes and minimum levels
Planned altitudes and flight levels
Fuel calculations (records of in-flight fuel checks)
Fuel on board when starting the engine
Alternates for destination, take-off and en-route, if applicable
Initial ATS flight plan clearance and subsequent re-clearance
In-flight re-planning calculations
Relevant meteorological information

Reference is made to OM Annex 01 – EuroPilot Center Operational Flight Plan.

6.1.14 Flight over Water

In accordance with NCO.IDE.A.175, the airplane shall be equipped with a life-jacket for each person on board (or equivalent individual flotation device) for each person on board younger than 24 months, that shall be worn or stowed in a position that is readily accessible from the seat or berth of the person for whose use it is provided:

When operating the Cessna C172SP over water beyond gliding distance from land; or taking off or landing at an aerodrome or operating site where, in the opinion of the pilot-in-command, the take-off or approach path is so disposed over water that there would be a likelihood of a ditching;
When operating the Cessna C172SP or Diamond DA42 at a distance away from land where an emergency landing is possible greater than that corresponding to 30 minutes at normal cruising speed or 50 NM, whichever is less.

The pilot-in-command of an airplane operated at a distance away from land where an emergency landing is possible greater than that corresponding to 30 minutes at normal cruising speed or 50 NM, whichever is the lesser, shall determine the risks to survival of the occupants of the airplane in the event of a ditching, based on which he/she shall determine the carriage of:

Equipment for making the distress signals;
Life-rafts in sufficient numbers to carry all persons on board, stowed so as to facilitate their ready use in emergency; and
Life-saving equipment, to provide the means of sustaining life, as appropriate to the flight to be undertaken.

4.2.5.2 Continuous Descent Final Approach Procedure (CDFA)
The CDFA technique should ensure that an approach can be flown on the desired vertical path and track in a stabilized manner, without significant vertical path changes during the final approach segment descent to the runway.

This technique applies to an approach with no vertical guidance and controls the descent path until the DA/H.

This descent path can be either a:
• Recommended descent rate, based on estimated ground speed;
• Descent path depicted on the approach chart; or
• Descent path coded in the flight management system in accordance with the approach chart descent path.

Note: The published Jeppesen Charts used by EuroPilot Center will satisfy the requirement whereby the appropriate cross check altitudes/heights with the corresponding appropriate range information are shown. The Missed Approach Point (MAPt) is published on these chart.

Note: The required descent path should be flown to the DA/H, observing any step-down crossing altitudes if applicable.

Note: As this is a DA/H no add-on to the published Jeppesen Approach minimums is required.

Note: Standard Minima Callouts should be performed when approaching the DA/H.

Note: The missed approach should be initiated no later than reaching the MAPt or at the DA/H, whichever comes first. The lateral part of the missed approach should be flown via the MAPt unless otherwise stated on the approach chart.

The minimum fuel required must be computed before each flight, based on:
Forecast meteorological conditions;

8.3.3 Fire hazard of Portable Electronic Devices

PED’s with lithium batteries are capable of ignition and subsequent explosion due to overheating. Overheating may be caused by shorting, rapid discharge or overcharging.

Overheating results in thermal runaway, which is a chemical reaction within the battery causing the internal temperature and pressure to rise.

This produces a fire that repeatedly flares up as each battery cell in turn ruptures and releases its contents.

Fighting a fire that contains either disposable or rechargeable lithium battery cells requires:

Extinguishment of the fire; and
Cooling of the remaining cells to stop the thermal runaway.

Water is the most effective coolant.

Halon, Halon replacement and/or water fire extinguishers should be used for initial knockdown of these fires, followed by immediate dousing with water from any available source.

Note: Do not use fire resistant burn bags to isolate burning lithium-type batteries. Transferring a burning appliance into a burn bag may be extremely hazardous.

Do not move the device until you are certain the fire is extinguished and the device is cool.

Apply the appropriate Cabin Fire Emergency procedures and land as soon as possible.

4.2.7 Commencement and continuation of approach – Approach Ban (NCO.OP.210)
The PIC may commence an instrument approach regardless of the reported runway visual range/visibility (RVR/VIS).

If the reported RVR/VIS is less than the applicable minimum, the approach shall not be continued:
• Below 1.000 ft above the aerodrome; or
• Into the final approach segment in the case where the decision altitude/height (DA/H) or minimum descent altitude/height (MDA/H) is more than 1.000 ft above the aerodrome.

Where the RVR is not available, RVR values may be derived by converting the reported visibility as described under 4.2.5.4.

If, after passing 1.000 ft above the aerodrome, the reported RVR/VIS falls below the applicable minimum, the approach may be continued to DA/H or MDA/H.

The approach may be continued below DA/H or MDA/H and the landing may be completed provided that the visual reference adequate for the type of approach operation and for the intended runway is established at the DA/H or MDA/H and is maintained.

The touchdown zone RVR shall always be controlling.

4.2.4.1 General
Take off minima must be expressed as visibility or RVR limits, taking into account all relevant factors for each aerodrome planned to be used and the Aircraft characteristics. Where there is a specific need to see and avoid obstacles on departure and/or for a forced landing, additional conditions (e.g. ceiling) must be specified.

The PIC shall not commence take off unless the weather conditions at the aerodrome of departure are equal to or better than applicable minima for landing at that aerodrome, unless a suitable take off alternate aerodrome is available.

When the reported meteorological visibility is below the required take off minima and RVR is not reported, a take off may only be commenced if the PIC can determine that the RVR/visibility along the take off runway is equal to or better than the required minimum.

When no reported meteorological visibility or RVR are available, a take off may only be commenced if the PIC can determine that the RVR/visibility along the take off runway is equal to or better than the required minimum.

6.1.10 Supplemental Oxygen

In accordance with NCO.OP.190, the pilot-in-command shall ensure that all flight crew members engaged in performing duties essential to the safe operation of an aircraft in flight use supplemental oxygen continuously whenever he/she determines that at the altitude of the intended flight the lack of oxygen might result in impairment of the faculties of crew members, and shall ensure that supplemental oxygen is available to passengers when lack of oxygen might harmfully affect passengers.

In any other case when the pilot-in-command cannot determine how the lack of oxygen might affect all occupants on board, he/she shall ensure that:

All crew members engaged in performing duties essential to the safe operation of an aircraft in flight use supplemental oxygen for any period in excess of 30 minutes when the pressure altitude in the passenger compartment will be between 10,000 ft and 13,000 ft; and
All occupants use supplemental oxygen for any period that the pressure altitude in the passenger compartment will be above 13,000 ft.

1.3.1 Landing performance C172SP
Since the only Landing requirement for a Single Engine aircraft is the Field Length, the Pilot In Command must ensure that:

The landing distance, from a screen height of 50 ft, must not exceed 70 % of the Landing Distance Available (LDA), i.e. a factor of 1,43.

Ground procedures (Ref. NCO.OP.165)
The pilot-in-command shall only commence take-off if the aircraft is clear of any deposit that might adversely affect the performance or controllability of the aircraft, except as permitted in the AFM.

2.1.1 Use of Checklists
The standard way of operating the aircraft in single-pilot operations is by means of checklists. There are three types of checklists:

Scan flows
Read and do
Recall

Scan flows are performed from top to bottom and from left to right. Every instrument and switch in the cockpit is checked in a logical order and the required actions are performed for the relevant phase of flight. Scan flows can be performed both on the ground and in flight.

Read-and-do checklists are performed only on the ground, with the exception of specific emergency checklists. An item is read out and thereafter the required action is performed.

Recall checklists are performed by heart. All in-flight checklists are recall checklists and must be known by heart at all times.

All checklists must be carried out loud and clear and announced, for example “Before Start Checklist”, and finished with “Before Start Checklist Completed”.

0.6 DEFINITIONS AND TERMS

Aerobatic flight: Intentional manoeuvres involving abrupt attitude changes not required for normal flight or instruction.
Aircraft: Any machine that can derive support in the atmosphere from the reactions of the air.
Flight time: Total time from the moment an aircraft first moves for the purpose of taking off until the moment it finally comes to rest at the end of the flight.
Instrument flight time: Time during which a pilot controls an aircraft solely by reference to instruments.
Pilot-in-Command (PIC): The pilot designated as responsible for the safe conduct of the flight.
Student Pilot-in-Command (SPIC): A student pilot acting as pilot-in-command under the supervision of a flight instructor.

2.4.1 Meteorological Conditions
In accordance with NCO.OP.160 (b) the PIC shall only commence or continue an IFR training flight towards the planned destination aerodrome if the latest available meteorological information indicates that at the estimated time of arrival, the weather conditions:
At the destination are at or above the applicable aerodrome operating minima as described under 4.2; or
At least one destination alternate aerodrome is at or above the applicable aerodrome operating minima described under 4.2.

Note: If a flight contains VFR and IFR segments, the meteorological information referred to in 2.3 and 2.4 above and shall be applicable as far as relevant.

201 ft – 300 ft | 1.000 m
More than 300 ft | 1.500 m

Note: 1.500 m is also applicable if no positive take-off flight path can be constructed.

As the C172SP is a single engine airplane, no positive take off path can be constructed after an engine failure, consequently the minimum take off RVR/VIS for all IFR training operations within EuroPilot Center will be 1.500 m.

For the DA42, the assumed Engine Failure Height is considered more than 300 ft, consequently the minimum take off RVR/VIS for all IFR training operations will be 1.500 m.

8.3.2 Restriction on use of Portable Electronic Devices during training operations

In accordance with NCO.GEN.125, the pilot-in-command shall not permit any person to use a portable electronic device (PED) on board an aircraft that could adversely affect the performance of the aircraft’s systems and equipment.

Precautions should also be taken to eliminate any fire hazard.

9.1.6 Collision avoidance
The student and/or instructor must ensure:

All windshields and side windows are clean and clear of obstructions.
Selecting the correct flight altitudes.
Applying the proper pattern entry procedure and subsequently flying the proper pattern.
Remaining alert at all times in the air and on the ground and using the proper traffic scanning method.

2.3 Limitations

All aircraft shall be operated in accordance with the applicable operating limitations as described in the Pilot Operating Handbook (POH).

For the Cessna C172SP – G1000, reference is made to POH Part 2 – Operating Limitations, Chapters 2-4 through 2-23.

For the Diamond DA42, reference is made to POH Section 1 – Limitations, Pages 2-4 through 2-36.

9.1.1 Visual look-out
The general rule to maintain a visual look-out to avoid collision with other flying objects or obstacles shall be enforced during VFR flights, VFR portions enroute and visual circuits.

Special attention must be paid to the traffic situation at or in the vicinity of a VFR aerodrome or an aerodrome with mixed VFR and IFR traffic.

4.2.4 Preparation

Students are required to be present at EuroPilot Center, minimum 30 minutes before the scheduled time in the online planning system.

A student should have prepared his flight as described in the Operations Manual Part 3, Chapter 2.1.

The instructor will integrate a check of the student’s preparation during the preflight briefing.

2.4.3 Specification of Isolated Aerodromes
In accordance with NCO.OP.105 for the selection of alternate aerodromes and the fuel policy, the PIC shall consider an aerodrome as an isolated aerodrome if the flying time to the nearest adequate destination alternate aerodrome is more than 60 minutes for airplanes with reciprocating engines.
